import numpy as np 
import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
from numpy import median
source.885a4e3c:
# Change this scatter plot to have percent literate on the y-axis
sns.scatterplot( y=df['Literacy (%)'], x=df['GDP ($ per capita)'])

# Show plot
plt.show()
source.41c31fec:

sns.countplot(y=df['Region'])
# Show plot

source.0c70de07:
# Create a scatter plot of absences vs. final grade
sns.scatterplot(x="absences", y="G3",data=students, hue="location")
# Show plot
plt.show()
source.0f95dbe2:
# Create a dictionary mapping subgroup values to colors
palette_colors = {"Rural": "green", "Urban": "blue"}

# Create a count plot of school with location subgroups
sns.countplot(x="school", data=students,
              hue="location",
              palette=palette_colors)

# Display plot
plt.show()
source.a3272ac8:
# Adjust further to add subplots based on family support
sns.relplot(x="G1", y="G3", 
            data=students,
            kind="scatter", 
            col="schoolsup",
            col_order=["yes", "no"],
            row="famsup",
            row_order=["yes", "no"])

# Show plot
plt.show()
source.a8f800c7:
# Create scatter plot of horsepower vs. mpg
sns.relplot(x="horsepower", y="mpg", 
            data=mpg, kind="scatter", 
            size="cylinders",
            hue="cylinders")

# Show plot
plt.show()
source.e6558d72:
# Create a scatter plot of acceleration vs. mpg
sns.relplot(x="acceleration", y="mpg", 
            data=mpg, kind="scatter", 
            style="origin", hue="origin")

# Show plot
plt.show()
source.fc3161bd:
# Make the shaded area show the standard deviation
sns.relplot(x="model_year", y="mpg",
            data=mpg, kind="line",ci="sd")

# Show plot
plt.show()
source.6d2d3b7c:
# Add markers and make each line have the same style
sns.relplot(x="model_year", y="horsepower", 
            data=mpg, kind="line", 
            ci=None, style="origin", 
            hue="origin", markers=True,
            dashes=False)

# Show plot
plt.show()
source.a6ac79ef:
#create new column "Age Category" based on Age
survey_data["Age Category"] = np.where(survey_data["Age"] < 21, "less than 21", "21+")
survey_data.head()
source.6f339f07:
# Create column subplots based on age category
sns.catplot(y="Internet usage", data=survey_data,
            kind="count",
            col="Age Category")

# Show plot
plt.show()
source.284da48c:
#create new boolean column Interested in Math

survey_data["Interested in Math"] = np.where(survey_data["Mathematics"] >3, True, False)

# Create a bar plot of interest in math, separated by gender
sns.catplot(x="Gender", y="Interested in Math",
            data=survey_data, kind="bar")

# Show plot
plt.show()
source.7312640d:
# List of categories from lowest to highest
category_order = ["<2 hours", 
                  "2 to 5 hours", 
                  "5 to 10 hours", 
                  ">10 hours"]

# Rearrange the categories
sns.catplot(x="study_time", y="G3",
            data=students,
            kind="bar",
            order=category_order)

# Show plot
plt.show()
source.a786566e:
# Specify the category ordering
study_time_order = ["<2 hours", "2 to 5 hours", 
                    "5 to 10 hours", ">10 hours"]

# Create a box plot and set the order of the categories
sns.catplot(x="study_time", y="G3", data=students,
kind="box", order=study_time_order)


# Show plot
plt.show()
source.68c6d915:
# Create a box plot with subgroups and omit the outliers
sns.catplot(x="internet", y="G3",
            data=students,
            kind="box",
            hue="location",
            sym="")

# Show plot
plt.show()
source.2b79194d:
# Set the whiskers to 0.5 * IQR
sns.catplot(x="romantic", y="G3",
            data=students,
            kind="box",
            whis = 0.5)

# Show plot
plt.show()

source.eebcba09:
# Add caps to the confidence interval
sns.catplot(x="famrel", y="absences",
            data=students,
            kind="point"
            , capsize=0.2)
        
# Show plot
plt.show()
source.d7732683:
# Create a point plot with subgroups
#use the median function that we've imported from numpy to display the median number of 
#absences instead of the average.

sns.catplot(x="romantic",y="absences",data=students,kind="point", hue="school", estimator=median)


# Show plot
plt.show()
source.74bb0fec:
# Set the style to "whitegrid"
sns.set_style("whitegrid")

# Create a count plot of survey responses
category_order = ["Never", "Rarely", "Sometimes", "Often", "Always"]

sns.catplot(x="Parents Advice", 
            data=survey_data, 
            kind="count", 
            order=category_order)

# Show plot
plt.show()
source.2f3dbdcb:

category_order = ["Never", "Rarely", "Sometimes", 
                  "Often", "Always"]

sns.catplot(x="Parents Advice",

            kind="count", 
            order=category_order)

plt.show()

source.eccc72fe:
# Set the style to "darkgrid"
sns.set_style("darkgrid")

# Set a custom color palette
sns.set_palette(["#39A7D0", "#36ADA4"])

# Create the box plot of age distribution by gender
sns.catplot(x="Gender", y="Age", 
            data=survey_data, kind="box")

plt.show()
source.8dd56241:
# Create scatter plot
g = sns.relplot(x="weight", 
                y="horsepower", 
                data=mpg,
                kind="scatter")

# Add a title "Car Weight vs. Horsepower"
g.fig.suptitle("Car Weight vs. Horsepower")
# Show plot
plt.show()
source.6279972e:
# Create line plot
g = sns.lineplot(x="model_year", y="mpg", 
                 data=mpg,
                 hue="origin")

# Add a title "Average MPG Over Time"
g.set_title("MPG Over Time")
# Show plot
plt.show()
source.ea2868b1:
# Create line plot
g = sns.lineplot(x="model_year", y="mpg", 
                 data=mpg,
                 hue="origin",
                ci=None)

# Add a title "Average MPG Over Time"
g.set_title("MPG Over Time")
# Add x-axis and y-axis labels
g.set(xlabel="Car Model Year",ylabel="MPG")

plt.show()
source.6da1632c:
# Create point plot
sns.catplot(x="origin",    y="acceleration", 
            data=mpg, 
            kind="point", 
            join=False, 
            capsize=0.1)
# Rotate x-tick labels
plt.xticks(rotation=90)

# Show plot
plt.show()
source.ab48116f: survey_data["Interested in Pets"] = np.where(survey_data["Pets"] >3, True, False)
source.0d5bbed7:
# Set palette to "Blues"
sns.set_palette("Blues")

# Adjust to add subgroups based on "Interested in Pets"
g = sns.catplot(x="Gender",
                y="Age", data=survey_data, 
                kind="box", hue="Interested in Pets")

# Set title to "Age of Those Interested in Pets vs. Not"
g.fig.suptitle("Age of Those Interested in Pets vs. Not")

# Show plot
plt.show()
source.15c466d2:
# Set the figure style to "dark"
sns.set_style("dark")

# Adjust to add subplots per gender
g = sns.catplot(x="Village - town", y="Likes Techno", 
                data=survey_data, kind="bar",
                col="Gender")

# Add title and axis labels
g.fig.suptitle("Percentage of Young People Who Like Techno", y=1.02)
g.set(xlabel="Location of Residence", 
      ylabel="% Who Like Techno")

# Show plot
plt.show()

source.eb56ec42:
**FacetGrid vs. AxesSubplot objects**

**FacetGrid: relplot(),catplot() ->Can create subplots**

**AxesSubplot: scatterplot(),countplot() -> Only creates a single plot**
